contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Saul was weak and using the spear to support himself or 2) Saul was attempting to kill himself by falling on his own spear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: Saul was leaning on his spear

contextId.information: Here "fallen" is a polite way of referring to being killed. Also, "sword" represents a battle. AT: "they had died in battle" or "enemies had killed them in battle" This here means "had been killed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they had fallen by the sword

contextId.information: This is a polite way of saying they died. AT: "they both died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

This rhetorical question is used to force Joab to acknowledge that continued fighting could only result in more suffering. Here "bitter" is a euphemism for the terrible suffering that would occur. AT: "You know very well that there will be a terrible result if this continues!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know it will be bitter in the end?

contextId.information: This is a polite way of saying that Amnon raped his sister. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
